children.title: Intro
children.description: English is a global lingua franca and a West Germanic language that evolved in medieval England. Today, it is the primary language of international business, science, and technology. With over 1.5 billion speakers, learning English connects you to a vast world of culture, travel, and professional opportunity.
children.content:
English is a West Germanic language that originated in early medieval England. 
While it started on a small island, it has become the world’s most widely spoken language. 
It is unique because its vocabulary is a "melting pot"—about 26% comes from Germanic roots, but nearly 58% comes from French and Latin.

The Global Lingua Franca
English is known as a lingua franca, meaning it is the common language used by people who do not share a native tongue.
Official Language: It is the official language of 67 different countries.
Primary Domains: It is the "universal language" of international business, aviation, science, technology, and the internet.

Speaker Count: There are roughly 1.5 billion English speakers worldwide, but only about 400 million are native speakers. 
This means most English conversations happen between non-native speakers!

Varieties of English
English isn't just one "thing." Depending on where you are, the accent, spelling, and vocabulary change. 

The two most common standards taught are:
British English (BrE): e.g., Colour, Centre, Lift.
American English (AmE): e.g., Color, Center, Elevator.

children.title: Sounds
children.content:
English is not a "phonetic" language—meaning we don't always say a word the way it's spelled 

Consonants (24 Sounds)
Consonant sounds are made by restricting airflow using your lips, teeth, or tongue.
Voiced: Your vocal cords vibrate (e.g., /b/ in "bat", /v/ in "van").
Voiceless: No vibration, just air (e.g., /p/ in "pat", /f/ in "fan").
Digraphs: Two letters making one sound (e.g., /sh/ in "ship", /th/ in "think").

Vowels (20 Sounds)
Vowels are the "musical" part of the language where air flows freely. 
Even though we only have 5 vowel letters (A, E, I, O, U), they create 20 sounds:
Short Vowels: Quick sounds like /æ/ in "cat" or /ɪ/ in "sit".
Long Vowels: Stretched sounds like /iː/ in "sheep" or /uː/ in "blue".
The Schwa ( /ə/ ): The most common sound in English! 
It’s a weak, neutral sound often found in unstressed syllables (like the "a" in about or the "e" in teacher).

3. Diphthongs (The "Gliding" Vowels)
These occur when two vowel sounds "glide" together in one syllable to create a new sound.
Examples: /aɪ/ as in "sky", /ɔɪ/ as in "boy", and /eɪ/ as in "face".

IPA Chart : https://www.internationalphoneticassociation.org/IPAcharts/IPA_charts_TI/IPA_charts_TI.html#eng

children.title: Letters
children.content:
Alphabet Name: How we say the letter when spelling (e.g., "A" sounds like "Ay").
Letter Sound: How the letter actually sounds in a word (e.g., the "A" in "apple" sounds like /æ/).

The Alphabet Breakdown
The English alphabet is divided into two functional groups:
Vowels (5): A, E, I, O, U (and sometimes Y). 
These are the "soul" of every syllable; almost every English word must contain at least one vowel letter.
Consonants (21): B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N, P, Q, R, S, T, V, W, X, Y, Z.

The Case System
English uses a "dual-case" system. It is essential for learners to know when to switch between them:
Uppercase (Capital): Used for the start of sentences, the pronoun "I," and Proper Nouns.
Lowercase: Used for everything else.

Letter Combinations (Graphemes)
Since we have more sounds than letters, English uses "Graphemes"—groups of letters that represent a single sound.
Digraphs: Two letters, one sound (e.g., SH in "fish", CH in "chip", PH in "phone").
Trigraphs: Three letters, one sound (e.g., TCH in "watch", IGH in "night").
Silent Letters: Letters that appear in writing but are not pronounced (e.g., the K in "knife" or the W in "write").

children.title: Syllables
children.content:
Think of a syllable as a single "unit" of pronunciation.

What makes a Syllable?
The golden rule in English is: One vowel sound = One syllable. 
It doesn't matter how many letters are in a word; what matters is how many vowel sounds you hear.
Cat: One vowel sound (1 syllable).
Apple: Two vowel sounds (2 syllables: Ap-ple).
Education: Four vowel sounds (4 syllables: Ed-u-ca-tion).

Why do Syllables matter? (The "Clap" Test)
The Clap Test: Clap every time you hear a beat in a word.
The Chin Drop: Put your hand under your chin. Every time your mouth opens for a vowel sound, your chin will drop. Each drop is one syllable.

Word Stress (The "Key" to English Rhythm)
This is the most important part of teaching syllables. In English, we do not say every syllable with the same strength. 
One syllable is always louder, longer, and higher in pitch.
PHO-to-graph (Stress on 1st)
pho-TOG-ra-pher (Stress on 2nd)
pho-to-GRAPH-ic (Stress on 3rd)

Changing the stress can sometimes change the meaning. For example:
RE-cord (Noun: a music disc)
re-CORD (Verb: to film or tape something)

children.title: Intonation & Flow
children.content:
Intonation: The 'music' of the language. Pitch rising or falling changes meaning (Questions go up, Statements go down).
Connected Speech: Native speakers link words together.
Linking: 'Black cat' -> 'Blackat'.
Elision: Dropping sounds (e.g., 'Next day' -> 'Nex day').

children.title: Words
children.content:
Words act as the bridge between raw letters and meaningful communication.

The Building Blocks: Morphemes
A word isn't just a random string of letters; it’s often made of smaller units of meaning called morphemes.
Root Words: The core part of the word that holds the main meaning (e.g., in "unplayable," the root is play).
Prefixes: Added to the front to change meaning (e.g., unhappy, redo, preview).
Suffixes: Added to the end to change the grammatical function (e.g., player [noun], playful [adjective], played [past tense]).

Word Formation Processes
English is very flexible. We create new words in several ways:
Compounding: Joining two whole words together (Sun + flower = Sunflower).
Blending: Mixing parts of words (Smoke + Fog = Smog).
Conversion: Using the same word as different parts of speech (e.g., "I will email [verb] you" vs. "I sent an email [noun]").

Word Relationships (Lexis)
Synonyms: Words with similar meanings (Big / Large).
Antonyms: Words with opposite meanings (Hot / Cold).
Homophones: Words that sound the same but have different spellings and meanings (Sea / See, Their / There).

Collocations (Natural Word Pairs) - Some words just "fit" together naturally in English.
Correct: Fast food, Make a mistake, Take a photo.
Natural but awkward: Quick food, Do a mistake, Make a photo.

children.title: Parts of Speech
children.content:
1. The "Naming" Words
Nouns: People, places, things, or ideas (e.g., London, teacher, phone, freedom).
Pronouns: Words that replace nouns to avoid repetition (e.g., he, she, it, they, someone).

2. The "Action" Words
Verbs: These express actions or states of being. They are the engine of the sentence (e.g., run, jump, is, seem).

3. The "Describing" Words
Adjectives: These describe or modify nouns (e.g., blue sky, fast car, happy child).
Adverbs: These describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They often end in -ly and tell us how, when, or where (e.g., ran quickly, very cold).

4. The "Relationship" Words
Prepositions: These show the relationship in time or space between words (e.g., on the table, after lunch, between friends).
Conjunctions: These connect words, phrases, or clauses together (e.g., and, but, or, because).

5. The "Emotion" Words
Interjections: Short exclamations used to express strong feelings or sudden emotion (e.g., Ouch!, Wow!, Oh!).

children.title: Vocabulary
children.content:
Vocabulary (or Lexis) is the collection of words that a person knows. 
While "Parts of Speech" teaches you the roles words play, the Vocabulary section focuses on the meaning and usage of those words in real life.

1. Semantic Fields (Word Grouping)
Instead of learning random words, students should learn words in "families" or themes. This makes memorization much easier.
Themed Lists: Kitchen (stove, whisk, sauté), Emotions (ecstatic, somber, anxious), or Business (revenue, deadline, stakeholder).

2. Synonyms and Antonyms
This helps learners vary their speech so they don't use the same word (like "good" or "bad") repeatedly.
Synonyms (Similar): Happy → Content, Cheerful, Joyful.
Antonyms (Opposite): Happy → Sad, Miserable, Depressed.

3. Denotation vs. Connotation
Denotation: The literal dictionary definition.
Connotation: The emotional feeling a word carries.
Example: "Cheap" and "Inexpensive" both mean low cost, but "Cheap" often implies poor quality, whereas "Inexpensive" sounds like a good deal.

4. Idioms and Phrasal Verbs
These are the most challenging but essential parts of English vocabulary because their meaning cannot be guessed from the individual words.
Idioms: "Piece of cake" (Very easy).
Phrasal Verbs: A verb + a preposition that creates a new meaning.
Example: "Give up" (Stop trying) vs. "Give away" (Donate).

children.title: Phrasal Verbs
children.content:
A phrasal verb is simply a verb + a particle (a preposition or adverb) that creates a meaning different from the original verb.


Preposition categories
1. The "UP" Category
In English, "Up" often signals completion, improvement, or an increase.
Clean up: To clean something completely.
Eat up: To finish all the food on your plate.
Cheer up: To become happier (improving mood).
Speak up: To speak louder (increasing volume).
Warm up: To prepare for exercise or heat something.

2. The "OFF" Category
"Off" usually implies separation, departure, or cancellation.
Take off: To leave the ground (plane) or remove clothing.
Set off: To start a journey.
Call off: To cancel an event.
Cut off: To disconnect (like a phone call) or interrupt.
Put off: To delay or postpone (separating the task from the present time).

3. The "OUT" Category
"Out" often means removing something, discovering information, or performing until the end.
Work out: To exercise or to solve a problem.
Find out: To discover a fact.
Hand out: To distribute things to a group.
Wear out: To use something until it’s broken or to be very tired.
Run out: To have none left (e.g., "We ran out of milk").

4. The "DOWN" Category
"Down" frequently suggests reduction, stopping, or recording.
Cut down: To reduce the amount of something (e.g., "Cut down on sugar").
Turn down: To decrease volume or to reject an offer.
Settle down: To become calm or start a stable life.
Write down: To record information on paper.
Break down: To stop working (machinery) or to lose emotional control.


5. The "ON" Category
"On" usually implies attachment, starting a process, or continuation.
Carry on / Keep on: To continue doing something.
Turn on / Switch on: To start a machine or light.
Put on: To dress yourself or to place something on a surface.
Get on: To enter a bus, train, or plane (also means to have a good relationship).
Hold on: To wait for a short time.

6. The "BACK" Category
"Back" almost always signals a return to a previous state, place, or person.
Give back: To return something to its owner.
Call back: To return a telephone call.
Get back: To return to a place.
Look back: To think about the past.
Pay back: To return money you borrowed.

7. The "AWAY" Category
"Away" suggests distance, disappearance, or continuous/aimless action.
Go away: To leave a place.
Give away: To give something for free or to reveal a secret.
Put away: To place something in its proper storage place (out of sight).
Pass away: A polite way to say someone has died (disappeared from life).
Throw away: To put something in the trash.

8. The "THROUGH" Category
"Through" usually indicates completing a process from start to finish or enduring a difficulty.
Go through: To experience a difficult situation or to examine something in detail.
Get through: To finish a task or to successfully contact someone.
Look through: To read or examine something quickly.
Sleep through: To continue sleeping despite a loud noise or event.

9. The "IN / INTO" Category
"In" or "Into" typically involves entering, involving yourself, or transforming.
Drop in: To visit someone without an appointment.
Fill in: To add information to a form or document.
Break in: To enter a building by force.
Look into: To investigate or research (looking "inside" a problem).
Turn into: To become something else (transformation).


10. The "OVER" Category
"Over" usually implies repetition, thoroughness, or a transition from one side to another.
Look over: To examine or check something (like a contract).
Think over: To consider something carefully before making a decision.
Talk over: To discuss a problem with someone.
Go over: To review or repeat information to ensure it's understood.
Take over: To gain control of something (like a company or a task).

11. The "AROUND / ROUND" Category
"Around" often suggests aimlessness, lack of purpose, or avoiding a direct path.
Hang around: To stay in a place for no particular reason.
Fool around: To behave in a silly or irresponsible way.
Shop around: To compare prices at different stores before buying.
Get around: To move from place to place or to avoid a problem.

12. The "BY" Category
"By" is often related to closeness (physical or temporal) or briefly stopping.
Stop by / Drop by: To visit someone for a short time.
Get by: To have just enough money or knowledge to survive a situation.
Stand by: To support someone or to be ready to help.
Go by: To pass (used for time or physical movement).

13. The "FOR" Category
"For" almost always signals purpose, searching, or representation.
Look for: To search for something lost.
Ask for: To request something.
Apply for: To make a formal request (like for a job).
Stand for: To represent or mean (e.g., "NASA stands for...").


Adverb categories
1. The "ALONG" Category (Adverb of Progress/Company)
This adverb usually implies accompanying someone or making steady progress.
Get along: To have a friendly relationship with someone.
Tag along: To go somewhere with someone, especially when uninvited.
Come along: To accompany someone OR to make progress (e.g., "How is your project coming along?").
Play along: To pretend to agree with someone or a situation.

2. The "APART" Category (Adverb of Separation)
This describes the physical or emotional disintegration of something.
Fall apart: To break into pieces or to lose emotional control.
Take apart: To dismantle something (like a machine) to see how it works.
Tell apart: To be able to see the difference between two similar things.
Pull apart: To separate two things or people by force.

3. The "AHEAD" Category (Adverb of Future/Priority)
This focuses on planning, time, or being in front.
Plan ahead: To prepare for the future.
Get ahead: To be successful in your career or life.
Look ahead: To think about what will happen in the future.
Go ahead: To start or continue with a plan.

4. The "TOGETHER" Category (Adverb of Unity)
This focuses on collecting, organizing, or collaborating.
Get together: To meet socially.
Pull yourself together: To regain your self-control or composure.
Put together: To assemble something or create a plan.
Keep together: To remain as a single group or unit.


Prepositional Particle	Must have an object (a noun or pronoun) following it.	
"I ran into an old friend." (You can't just say "I ran into.")


Adverbial Particle	Often describes how/where. 
Can often stand alone without an object.	"The plane took off." (No object needed)

children.title: Meaning & Style
children.content:
Figurative Language: Using words creatively.
Metaphor: Comparison without 'like/as' (e.g., 'Time is money').
Simile: Comparison using 'like/as' (e.g., 'Busy as a bee').

Ambiguity:
Homonyms: Same spell/sound, different meaning (Bat: Animal vs. Baseball).
Polysemy: One word with related meanings (Head of body, Head of company).

children.title: Model Verbs
children.content:
They are "helper" verbs that express things like possibility, necessity, or permission.
1. The Golden Rules of Modals
Before learning the meanings, you must know the three grammar rules that apply to all modal verbs:
No "s" in the third person: We say "He can," not "He cans."
No "to" after the modal: We say "I must go," not "I must to go" (except for ought to).
No "do/does" in questions: We say "Can you help?" not "Do you can help?"

2. Categorizing Modals by "Function"
Category	Modal Verbs	                        Intensity/Usage
Ability	        Can, Could	                        Can (present), Could (past).
Permission	Can, May, Could	                May is the most formal.
Probability	Might, May, Could, Must	Must is 95% certain; Might is 20% certain.
Advice	        Should, Ought to	                Suggesting the "right" thing to do.
Obligation	Must, Have to	                Must (internal/strong); Have to (external rule).
Prohibition	Must not, Cannot	                You are not allowed to do it.


3. The "Certainty Scale"
One of the most important uses of modal verbs is showing how sure you are about something.
Low Certainty: "It might rain later." (Maybe 30% chance)
Medium Certainty: "It should rain later." (I expect it to happen)
High Certainty: "It must be raining." (I see people with umbrellas; I am 99% sure)

4. Modal Verbs in the Past
To use a modal in the past, we use: Modal + Have + Past Participle.
Regret: "I should have studied harder." (I didn't study, and now I'm sad).
Past Guess: "He must have forgotten the meeting." (I am sure that's why he isn't here).
Past Ability: "I could have won, but I tripped." (I had the potential, but it didn't happen).

children.title: Phrases
children.content:
A phrase is a group of two or more words that functions as a single unit within a sentence. 
The most important rule  is: A phrase does not have both a subject and a verb. If it had both, it would be a clause!

1. The Anatomy of a Phrase
Every phrase has a "Head Word." This is the most important word in the group that determines the phrase's category.
The big red bus (Head word: bus — this is a Noun Phrase).
Is walking (Head word: walking — this is a Verb Phrase).

2. Common Types of Phrases
A. Noun Phrases (NP)
Includes a noun and all its modifiers.
Example: "The hungry cat drank the milk."
B. Verb Phrases (VP)
Includes a main verb and its helping (auxiliary) verbs.
Example: "She has been studying all night."
C. Prepositional Phrases (PP)
Starts with a preposition and ends with a noun or pronoun. These usually tell us where or when.
Example: "The keys are on the wooden table."
D. Adjective Phrases
A group of words that describes a noun.
Example: "The movie was really very exciting."

children.title: Clauses
children.content:
Clauses are the "powerhouse" of the English language. 
While a phrase is just a group of words, 
a clause is a group of words that contains both a Subject (who/what) and a Predicate (the verb/action).

1. The Two Main Types of Clauses
For your learners, the most important distinction is between "Independent" and "Dependent."

A. Independent Clauses (The "Strong" Clause)
An independent clause expresses a complete thought and can stand alone as a full sentence.
Formula: Subject + Verb = Complete Thought.
Example: "She studied." (Simple, but complete).

B. Dependent Clauses (The "Weak" Clause)
A dependent clause (also called a subordinate clause) has a subject and a verb, but it cannot stand alone. 
It leaves the listener waiting for more information. It usually starts with a "marker word" (conjunction).
Formula: Conjunction + Subject + Verb = Incomplete Thought.
Example: "Because she studied..." (The listener asks: "What happened because she studied?")

2. The Components of a Clause
Subject: The person or thing doing the action (e.g., The cat).
Predicate: The action and everything following it (e.g., slept on the rug).

3. How they combine
This is where Syntax starts to get interesting. You can combine these clauses to create different sentence structures:
Independent + Independent: "I like coffee, and he likes tea."
Independent + Dependent: "I stayed home because it was raining."

children.title: Sentences
children.content:
This is where all the previous units—sounds, words, phrases, and clauses—come together to express a complete, logical thought.
A sentence must always begin with a capital letter, end with a punctuation mark (. ! ?), and contain at least one independent clause.

1. The 4 Structural Types
Depending on how many clauses you connect (and what kind), you create one of these four structures:
Simple Sentence: One independent clause.
Example: "The cat slept."
Compound Sentence: Two independent clauses joined by a conjunction (and, but, or).
Example: "The cat slept, and the dog barked."
Complex Sentence: One independent clause + at least one dependent clause.
Example: "The cat slept because it was tired."
Compound-Complex Sentence: Two or more independent clauses + at least one dependent clause.
Example: "The cat slept because it was tired, but the dog stayed awake."

2. The 4 Functional Types (Moods)
This explains the purpose of the sentence. 
Declarative: Makes a statement (ends with a period).
Example: "The sky is blue."
Interrogative: Asks a question (ends with a question mark).
Example: "Is the sky blue?"
Imperative: Gives a command or request.
Example: "Look at the sky."
Exclamatory: Expresses strong emotion (ends with an exclamation point).
Example: "What a beautiful sky!"

3. Sentence Anatomy (S-V-O)
The most common "blueprint" for an English sentence is the Subject-Verb-Object pattern.
Subject: Who is doing it? (The chef)
Verb: What is the action? (cooked)
Object: What is receiving the action? (the meal)

children.title: Puncuatation
children.content:
Punctuation tells the reader when to stop, when to pause, and what the tone of the message is.
1. The "Big Three" Terminal Marks
These appear at the end of a sentence and define its function.
Period ( . ): The full stop. Used for statements.
Example: "The class is over."
Question Mark ( ? ): Used at the end of a direct question.
Example: "Is the class over?"
Exclamation Point ( ! ): Used to show strong emotion or urgency.
Example: "The class is finally over!"

2. The Internal Marks (The Pauses)
These help organize ideas within a single sentence.
Comma ( , ): The most common mark. It creates a small "breath" or pause. We use it to separate items in a list or to join clauses with a conjunction.
Example: "I bought milk, bread, and eggs."
Semicolon ( ; ): Used to connect two independent clauses that are closely related in thought, without using a conjunction like "and" or "but."
Example: "I have a big test tomorrow; I can't go to the movies."
Colon ( : ): Used to introduce a list, a quote, or an explanation.
Example: "You need three things: a pen, paper, and a brain."
Apostrophe ( ' ): Used for two specific jobs: showing possession (John’s car) or creating contractions (Don’t for "do not").

3. Punctuation and Meaning
Changing a punctuation mark can completely change the meaning of a sentence. A famous example used in English teaching is:
Version A: "Let’s eat, Grandma!" (An invitation to dinner).
Version B: "Let’s eat Grandma!" (A suggestion to eat the person).

children.title: Types
children.content:
English has four main conditional types, categorized by how "real" or "likely" the situation is.

1. The Zero Conditional (General Truths)
Used for facts, scientific laws, or things that are always true.
Formula: If + Present Simple, [then] Present Simple.
Example: "If you heat ice, it melts."

2. The First Conditional (Real Possibilities)
Used for a specific future situation that is likely to happen.
Formula: If + Present Simple, [then] Will + Verb.
Example: "If it rains tomorrow, I will stay home."

3. The Second Conditional (Hypothetical/Imaginary)
Used for things that are not true right now or are very unlikely to happen (daydreaming).
Formula: If + Past Simple, [then] Would + Verb.
Example: "If I won the lottery, I would travel the world." (Note: "Won" is used for the "if" clause, but we are talking about the present/future).

4. The Third Conditional (Past Regrets)
Used for a past situation that did not happen. It is often used to express regret or imagine a different past.
Formula: If + Past Perfect, [then] Would Have + Past Participle.
Example: "If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam." (Reality: I didn't study, and I didn't pass).

children.title: Moods
children.content:
In grammar, "Mood" refers to the speaker's attitude or the "manner" in which a thought is expressed. 
It tells the listener if you are stating a fact, giving an order, or imagining something.

There are three primary moods in English:

1. The Indicative Mood (Facts)
This is the most common mood. It is used to state facts, opinions, or ask simple questions.
Purpose: To be objective and informative.
Example: "The sun rises in the east."
Example: "He is a student."

2. The Imperative Mood (Commands)
This mood is used to give orders, instructions, or make strong requests. The subject "You" is usually hidden (understood).
Purpose: To direct behavior.
Example: "Close the door."
Example: "Please sit down."

3. The Subjunctive Mood (Wishes & Possibilities)
This is the most "advanced" mood. It is used to express wishes, hypothetical situations, or things that are contrary to fact. It often uses a special verb form (like "were" instead of "was").
Purpose: To express a dream, a doubt, or a demand.
Example: "If I were you, I wouldn't do that." (Hypothetical)
Example: "I suggest that he arrive on time." (Recommendation)

children.title: Voices
children.content:
Voices describe the relationship between the action (the verb) and the person or thing performing that action (the subject).

There are two voices in English: Active and Passive. 
Understanding the difference is key to helping your learners control the "focus" of their sentences.

1. Active Voice (Direct & Strong)
In the active voice, the subject of the sentence performs the action. This is the most common way to speak and write because it is clear and direct.
Formula: [Subject] + [Verb] + [Object]
Example: "The chef (Subject) cooked (Verb) the meal (Object)."

2. Passive Voice (Indirect & Focused)
In the passive voice, the subject receives the action. We use this when the person doing the action is unknown, unimportant, or when we want to emphasize the result rather than the doer.
Formula: [Object] + [Be-Verb] + [Past Participle] + (by [Subject])
Example: "The meal (Object) was cooked (Be-Verb + Participle) by the chef."

3. When to use Passive Voice?
It is a common mistake for learners to think the Passive Voice is "wrong." It is actually very useful in specific contexts:
Scientific Writing: "The chemical was heated to 100°C." (Who heated it isn't the point).
News/Crime: "A bank was robbed last night." (We don't know who did it yet).
Politeness/Diplomacy: "The window was left open" sounds less accusatory than "You left the window open!"

children.title: Tenses
children.content:
Tenses are the most complex part of the Grammar block. 
If Words are the "bricks" and Syntax is the "blueprint," Tenses are the "clock" of the language. 
They tell us exactly when an action happened and whether that action is finished or ongoing.

English has 12 major tenses, organized by Time and Aspect.

1. The Three Time Periods
Every tense starts with one of these three:

Past: Something that happened before now.
Present: Something happening now or generally true.
Future: Something that will happen later.

2. The Four Aspects
The "Aspect" tells us the nature of the action:

Simple: A one-time or habitual action (e.g., I eat).
Continuous (Progressive): An ongoing action (e.g., I am eating).
Perfect: An action completed in relation to another time (e.g., I have eaten).
Perfect Continuous: An ongoing action that has been happening for a duration (e.g., I have been eating).

children.title: Modals & Speech
children.content:
Modal Verbs: Auxiliary verbs that express necessity or possibility.
Obligation: Must, Have to.
Ability: Can, Could.
Permission: May, Can.

Reported Speech: Telling someone what another person said.
Direct: He said, 'I am busy'.
Indirect: He said that he was busy (Tense shift back).

children.title: Speeches
children.content:
Speeches allow us to communicate what someone else has said. 
While Direct Speech is a literal quote, Indirect (Reported) Speech focuses on the message, adjusted for our current time and place.


1. The Core Transformation
When moving from Direct to Indirect speech, three things usually change: Pronouns, Tenses, and Time/Place expressions.
Direct: "I am happy here today," said Mary.
Indirect: Mary said (that) she was happy there that day.

2. The Tense "Backshift" Rule
To report something accurately, we usually move the verb one step back into the past.
Direct Speech                                             Indirect Speech (Reported)
Present Simple (eat)                                  Past Simple (ate)
Present Continuous (is eating)                 Past Continuous (was eating)
Present Perfect (has eaten)                      Past Perfect (had eaten)
Past Simple (ate)                                       Past Perfect (had eaten)
Will (will eat)                                             Would (would eat)
Can (can eat)                                             Could (could eat)


3. Reporting Questions
Questions are unique because the word order changes from a "question" format back to a "statement" format.
Wh- Questions: Keep the question word (Who, What, Where, Why, How).
Direct: "Where is the key?"
Indirect: He asked where the key was. (Not: where was the key)
Yes/No Questions: Use if or whether.
Direct: "Do you like coffee?"
Indirect: She asked if I liked coffee.

4. Commands and Requests
When reporting an order or a plea, we use the formula: Reporting Verb + Object + To-Infinitive.
Direct: "Sit down!" the teacher said.
Indirect: The teacher told us to sit down.
Direct: "Please don't smoke," she said.
Indirect: She asked him not to smoke.

5. Reporting Verbs: Adding Flavor
Using only "said" or "told" can be boring. We can use verbs that show the speaker's intent:
Agreement: admitted, agreed, complained
Information: explained, informed, mentioned
Persuasion: promised, suggested, warned
If the original statement is still true (e.g., "The sun rises in the east"), you don't have to backshift the tense, but doing so is never wrong!

children.title: Gerunds / Infinitives
children.content:
Think of these as the "double agents" of English: they look like verbs, but they function as the subject or object of a sentence.

1. The Gerund (-ing)
A gerund is the verb + ing (e.g., running, eating, swimming). We use it when we are talking about the activity in general.
As a Subject: "Smoking is bad for your health."
After Prepositions: "He is good at singing." (Always use a gerund after a preposition!)
Specific Verbs: Some verbs are almost always followed by a gerund:
Enjoy, finish, avoid, mind, suggest, keep.
Example: "I enjoy traveling." (Not: "I enjoy to travel.")

2. The Infinitive (to + Verb)
The infinitive is the "base" form of the verb, usually preceded by "to" (e.g., to run, to eat). It often expresses purpose or intent.
To show Purpose: "I went to the store to buy milk."
After Adjectives: "It is easy to learn English."
Specific Verbs: These verbs are usually followed by an infinitive:
Want, hope, need, decide, promise, plan.
Example: "I decided to stay." (Not: "I decided staying.")

3. The "Bare" Infinitive
Sometimes we use the infinitive without "to." This happens mostly after:
Modal Verbs: "I can speak French." (Not: "I can to speak.")
Let & Make: "She let him go." / "He made me laugh."

4. The "Change of Meaning" Verbs
Some verbs can take either a gerund or an infinitive, but the meaning changes completely!
Verb	         Followed by Gerund (-ing)	                                                                Followed by Infinitive (to)
Stop	        To quit an action. (I stopped smoking.)	                                        To pause an action to do another. (I stopped to smoke.)
Remember	To have a memory of the past. (I remember locking the door.)	To not forget a future task. (Remember to lock the door!)
Try	                To experiment with a new method. (Try adding salt.)	                To make a physical/mental effort. (Try to open the window.)

children.title: Communication
children.content:
In the world of English Language Teaching (ELT), we often distinguish between Usage (grammar) and Use (communication). Here are the three main areas you might want to add to make this a "complete" curriculum:

1. Pragmatics (Social Language)
This is about how we use language in specific contexts. A student can know perfect grammar but still sound rude or strange if they don't understand pragmatics.
Register: Choosing between Formal (business) vs. Informal (friends) language.
Politeness: How to use "hedging" (e.g., "I was wondering if..." instead of "I want...").
Idioms & Slang: Cultural expressions that don't follow literal dictionary definitions.

2. Discourse (Flow of Conversation)
While "Syntax" covers sentences, Discourse covers how those sentences connect to form a story or a conversation.
Cohesion: Using words like "However," "Therefore," and "In addition" to link ideas.
Turn-taking: The unspoken rules of how to start, maintain, and end a conversation.
Paragraphing: How to organize multiple sentences into a single topic block.

3. The "Four Skills"
Most language certifications (like IELTS or TOEFL) measure a student's ability across four practical domains. You might consider these as the "Output" of your grammar blocks:
Receptive Skills: Reading and Listening.
Productive Skills: Writing and Speaking.

children.title: Writing
children.content:
Structure:
Introduction (Hook + Thesis).
Body Paragraphs (Topic Sentence + Evidence).
Conclusion (Summary + Final Thought).

Genres:
Narrative: Telling a story.
Descriptive: Painting a picture with words.
Expository: Explaining facts.
Persuasive: Convincing the reader.
